results.title: Country children
results.creator_credit: Churches Television and Radio Centre and Chris Pettit
results.brief_description: A look at two young boys, aged about two and four, who are growing up on a farm that is run by their parents. The parents discuss the advantages of growing up in the country. They also talk about the problem of the boys being isolated from children their own age and how they overcome it by sending them to a regular playschool.

results.title: Country
results.creator_credit: Far West Productions, Pangaea Corporation, William D Whittliff, Jessica Lange and Richard Pearce
results.brief_description: A deeply-felt variation of the classic struggle of the working man versus the forces of government. Iowa farmers, Jewell and Gil Ivy (Jessica Lange and Sam Shephard) work a poor farm held by their family for generations. Shephard delivers a performance of immense integrity in his portrayal of a man humiliated because he is unable to provide for his family. The screenplay reflects recent events in the US where struggling farmers took on government loans to expand and wound up faced with foreclosure on their properties.

results.title: Counting the beat
results.creator_credit: Sue Clothier, Mushroom Pictures and Kimble Rendall
results.brief_description: Mushroom Records - founded by the charismatic Michael Gudinski, has proven to be one of the most influential independent Australian record labels. “Counting the beat” is a fascinating history of 25 years of Australian rock and roll, as well as tracing the label’s evolution - its birth with such seminal figures as Billy Thorpe and Chain, through the glitz and glamour of Skyhooks, the pop glory days of soap stars Kylie and Jason, the breakthrough of Paul Kelly, and international success with Nick Cave, Peter Andre and Garbage. Australian performers such as Kylie Minogue, Jimmy Barnes, Deborah Conway and Paul Kelly take this opportunity to discuss the evolution of their careers, their ups and downs through these intimate interviews are enlightening, as well as being interspersed with studio footage from their performances.

results.title: Counting on the future
results.creator_credit: Anne Boggan and United Nations Television
results.brief_description: A film about the population polices of five developing countries: Haiti, the Central African Republic, Ghana, Nigeria and Tanzania. Haiti, a crowded island with few resources, is contrasted with relatively uncrowded African nations rich in agricultural potential. Population planning for these countries begin with a census and education and family planning is accepted only after infant mortality has been sharply reduced. Narrated by Ruby Dee.

results.title: Countering sexism
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development, Sabina Baltrukomis, Julie Sheehan and Don Fitzsimmons
results.brief_description: A compilation tape of four programmes addressing various aspects of sex discrimination. The episodes highlight women working in the media, the importance of gender inclusive curriculum, girls and science and sexual harrassment in schools.

results.title: Counter attacks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Judo”.
Having learnt the many techniques and the various factors which influence the way these techniques are used, the next stop is to learn how they can be linked. There are two main linking techniques - defensive and offensively; defensive linkage is known as countering. Counter take several forms, the value of which will depend largely upon the attitude of the person using them. Specific counters demonstrated are osoto-gaeshi, uchi-mata-gaeshi, an ippon-seoi-counter, waki-gatame and speed counters.

results.title: Countdown
results.creator_credit: William Conrad, Warner Bros Pictures, Seven Arts Productions and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: The space-race between the United States and the Soviet Union reaches new heights when the Russians employ plans to send cosmonaughts directly to the moon. In the desperate attempt to be first, NASA sends Lee (James Caan) in an old style Gemini probe on a make-shift mission after three weeks training: to land on the Moon, and then live there for a year until rescued by the Apollo crew. This wry absurdity, directed by Altman after a ten year absence from filmmaking, makes great viewing for it depicts the US government as the “bad guy” and contains several anti-Cold War gestures. Screenplay by Loring Mandel. Based on the book, “Countdown” by Hank Searl.
